Lendlease's CEO in the Americas, Denis Hickey, said the company will make sure growth is "slow and measured" and built up with "local people in the marketplace".
output: LendLease to allocate 40-50% of capital to international growth

Instances.input: Growing numbers of Chinese entrepreneurs are turning to personalised, online micro-courses to fill their knowledge gaps, building an industry said to be worth an estimated CNY50bn ($7.7bn) at the end of 2017, according to a report by Alibaba. The boom has been attributed to convenient mobile payments and the growth of web users, as well as government efforts to protect internet copyright. Chen Liteng, from China E-Commerce Research Center, said content providers needed to tailor high-quality material to users with very limited time or fractured schedules.
output: Chinese micro-learning industry set for boom

Instances.input: More US houses could be sold with loans using bitcoin as collateral, with companies such as start-up Unchained Capital, based in Texas, among the first to offer bitcoin-backed loans of up to $1m. New laws that levy capital gains tax on those trading digital currencies could also make it a growth sector. "A loan is also better in the sense that you are unlocking some of the value of the bitcoin but you’re not disposing of the asset", said San Francisco-based lawyer Robert W Wood.
output: Unchained Capital to accept bitcoin as collateral for home loans

Instances.input: UK doctors aged over 30 need to get up to speed with advances in modern genomic medicine, warned Professor Patrick Chinnery, a member of the Medical Research Council and mitochondrial specialist at Cambridge University. Speaking to The Telegraph, Chinnery said medical students were being trained in how to use and interpret genomic testing, and before long it would become a part of the relicensing process, leaving older clinicians in need of education. However, the Royal College of General Practitioners has said under-pressure general practitioners may not have the time for additional training.
output: UK doctors not knowledgeable on genomic developments

Instances.input: Virtual- and augmented-reality (VR and AR) applications could benefit from research that managed for the first time to focus the whole visible spectrum of light onto one spot in high resolution using a single flat metalens. Harvard researchers revealed in Nature Nanotechnology how they used nanofins to overcome the different wavelengths of each colour of light to ensure they hit the same focal point at the same time. Metalenses, which are cheap and easy to make, could be used in cameras and other optical devices.
output: VR, AR could benefit from full-spectrum metalens breakthrough

Instances.input: Clubbers at Prague nightclub Karlovy Lazne have been dancing the night away to music chosen by a robot DJ, according to Reuters. The club's owners asked a robotics firm to repurpose a KUKA arm, previously used in car manufacturing, fitting it with software that allowed it to choose and change CDs, as well as dance. The robot, which alternates with a human DJ every hour, has been in service for several weeks.
output: KUKA arm robot DJ performs in Prague nightclub

Instances.input: Minnesota-based Ellingson Companies has developed Element, an analysis service which enables farmers to get the best return on investment from fields by optimising drain tiling. Element combines weather and soil data with crop rotation information and drainage theory to produce a drainage coefficient, which is used to calculate how much drainage is required and what the likely yield will be. Jason Gillard, vice president of operations at Ellingson, said the system allows farmers to make more informed, agronomy-based drainage decisions.
output: Element drives data-powered field management

Instances.input: Agricultural company Harvest Croo Robotics has begun field-testing a machine for harvesting strawberries, according to co-founder Gary Wishnatzki. Although the technology is in its early days, Harvest Croo is partnering with Sonoco to develop new packaging for fruit picked by the machine. Wishnatzki said around two-thirds of the strawberry-growing industry had invested in his firm, despite commercialisation of its machines being some years away.
output: Harvest Croo Robotics targets automated strawberry harvest

Instances.input: New York-based start-up Antuit has created CYFIRMA, a division which uses artificial intelligence to deliver threat intelligence to customers, according to a statement by co-founder Shiong Tan. The platform offers clients real-time, personalised insights into emerging threats, and information about tactics employed by hackers. Kumar Ritesh, CTO of CYFIRMA said: "There is now a clear requirement for improved application of contextual cyber threat intelligence to a company's overall cybersecurity posture".
output: Antuit offers AI-powered threat detection

Instances.input: The majority of agtech companies are embracing internet of things (IoT) technology, but fewer than a quarter believe they can cope with the cyber threats associated with the tech. The figures are part of a report commissioned by Inmarsat, and revealed that, of 100 global agtech firms, 45% said their methods to counter cyber-attacks could be more robust, while 55% said they needed additional security skills to develop IoT risk solutions. Inmarsat's Chris Harry-Thomas urged agtech firms to ensure IoT security was a top priority.
output: Farmers face cybersecurity risks posed by technology push

Instances.input: The UK's Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ) is struggling to retain expert cybersecurity staff, who are being lured to the private sector by tech companies that pay up to five times more, according to an annual report from the Intelligence and Security Committee of Parliament. The report said the level of government resources allocated to cyber-related activities had increased considerably, but GCHQ "struggles to attract and retain a suitable and sufficient cadre of in-house technical specialists".
output: Cybersecurity experts poached from GCHQ by private firms

Instances.input: A network of high-voltage direct current transmission lines carrying power from renewable resources could eliminate the need for energy storage and help to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 80% below 1990 levels inside 15 years, according to a study in Nature Climate Change. However, overlapping federal, state, county, and city jurisdictions, as well as a lack of incentive from utilities to pay for transmission lines has hampered their deployment and maintained a reliance on fossil fuels.
output: HVDC transmission lines could cut US greenhouse emissions by 80%

Instances.input: Healthureum is developing a blockchain-based platform aimed at bringing "transparency, security and accountability" to every aspect of health care. The Estonia-based start-up said the platform can be accessed using its Ethereum-based Healthureum Token digital currency, with a token generation event running from 10 January until 13 February. Healthureum's platform will manage patient data, enable interoperability between different hospitals, monitor the purchase, renting and servicing of medical equipment, and capture supply-chain data.
output: Start-up Healthureum launches crypto-based healthcare platform

Instances.input: Florida-based firm Magic Leap has released details of its augmented reality/mixed reality headset, the Magic Leap One: Creator Edition. Comprising goggles that include digital Lightfield technology, a mini-computer called a Lightpack and a hand-held controller, the device enables users to "actively create with the computer", according to Magic Leap founder Rony Abovitz, with uses including web browsing and gaming. While no price or availability details have been released, the company said a software development kit is set to go on sale early this year, with a product launch scheduled for later in 2018.
output: Magic Leap unveils its augmented reality headset

Instances.input: Flexible office space provider Regus – now part of IWG – has said it is in talks with Canadian companies Brookfield Asset Management and Onex Corporation over a potential £2.5bn ($3.4bn) cash buyout of the company. IWG shares rose by more than 27% after the news broke. IWG had a turbulent 2017 in the face of competition from WeWork and issued a profit warning in October. IWG founder Mark Dixon, who owns 25% of the business, could make as much as £600m from the sale. The Canadian companies have until 20 January to offer their proposal.
output: Regus IWG holds takeover talks with Onex Corporation, Brookfield Asset Management

Instances.input: With Amazon set on entering the insurance market, top-tier companies may seek to enter partnerships with the online marketplace. Amazon has recently been recruiting staff for an insurance division, declaring it's launching a new business line. The company already offers extended warranty services for goods under its Amazon Protect brand. Rather than put up resistance, leading insurers are likely to seek partnership arrangements with Amazon, according to industry consultant Pat Speer. Such arrangements would see Amazon treated in a similar vein to how smaller insurtech firms have been courted by incumbent insurers.
output: Top-tier insurers could attempt to partner with Amazon

Instances.input: A new analytical model for brownfield oil reservoirs uses the salinity of injected water to improve the understanding of fluid movements in the operation, said researchers from the Society of Petroleum Engineers. Charting the salinity of production water could help optimise water injection, promoting the most efficient methods and increasing oil recovery, they said. The model was applied to a large oil field in Egypt, where it helped improve understanding of critical issues across about 500 wells, including fluid contacts, well integrity, aquifer support, effect of faults, well zonation, and contribution of commingled wells.
output: Water salinity test could boost production from older wells

Instances.input: A former medium-security prison in Colorado has been put up for sale on Craigslist, with an asking price of $1.2m or 88 bitcoins. The move follows the recent revamp of US tax laws. The new code is set to benefit investors with shares in private prisons, as it reduces a tax on investments in real estate investment trusts to 29.6% from 39.6%.
output: Private prison for sale on Craiglist with 88-bitcoin asking price

Instances.input: Flexible office space providers WeWork and Regus are battling each other and smaller rivals for control of the still-growing South Florida marketplace. WeWork was set to open locations in Coral Gables and Miami by the end of 2017, focusing on attracting enterprise business clients. Regus already oversees five locations in South Florida, and plans to open its first Spaces-branded site in Miami early this year.
output: Regus Flexible space rivals jostle to dominate South Florida

Instances.input: The Bank of England (BoE) is considering the launch of a digital currency linked to sterling that would avoid the volatility of bitcoin. A research unit set up by the BoE in 2015 to study the feasibility of the project is set to report back within the next year or two. The announcement follows talks between BoE Governor Mark Carney and other central banks about launching cryptocurrencies. In March 2016, researchers from University College London developed the BoE-backed RSCoin.
output: BoE mulls creating cryptocurrency tied to sterling

Instances.input: Roughly 71% of 300 surveyed registered investment advisers in the US believe active strategies, rather than passive, will be the top performers in 2018, according to a study by InvestmentNews. Despite passive funds having outperformed their active counterparts on successive market gains, many advisers believe the current bull market can't last forever, and that active management has a tendency to perform better in down markets. The US stock market ended last year with roughly a 22% gain and has been up close to 300% since its low-point in 2009.
output: US advisers back active funds to outperform in 2018

Instances.input: Insufficient charging infrastructure for electric vehicles (EVs) is hampering the UK's move to autonomous cars, AXA UK & Ireland Group CEO Amanda Blanc has warned. The nation has 14,000 chargers for about 125,000 plug-in EVs. Blanc called for more rapid charging bays outside London and the south-east. She also said the government needed to be smarter with renewables to avoid putting a strain on the National Grid. "Imagine what will happen if everybody comes home from work at six o’clock and switches their cars on to charge," she said.
output: Lack of EV charging network damages UK growth of autonomous cars

Instances.input: UK telecoms company Openreach is behind schedule in bringing its G.fast broadband network to a million homes by the end of March, according to ispreview.co.uk. Openreach said it had covered 390,000 UK premises, but the slow progress could see further delays to the final Early Market Deployment phase. TalkTalk is currently running closed trials of the G.fast service and has remained tight-lipped about its launch plans.
output: TalkTalk Openreach ultrafast broadband rollout behind schedule

Instances.input: UK housebuilder Redrow is offering to pay up to £8,000 ($10,846) towards the cost of homes on its Devonshire Gardens development in Harrogate. The company said it will pay the sales taxes to sell the last dozen one- to five-bedroom properties on the Yorkshire estate. Patsy Aicken, sales director for Redrow Homes in Yorkshire, said more properties were planned for the site but construction would not begin for some time.
output: Redrow Final push to sell Yorkshire estate homes

Instances.input: Increasingly specialised smart-beta exchange-traded funds (ETF) focusing on specific sectors could sink "without a trace", warned Peter Sleep of Seven Investment Management, noting the same happened to shipbuilding and coal-mining focused products, reported David Thorpe in FT Adviser.
output: Seven IM warns against 'fashionable' ETFs

Instances.input: CBOE Global Markets has applied to list six bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The move comes following the exchange's launch of futures contracts focused on the cryptocurrency. The ETFs are managed by First Trust Advisors, REX ETFs and GraniteShares. Bitcoin dropped below $11,000 for a short time on Friday, marking a 44% drop from its high at the start of last week.
output: CBOE files with SEC for six bitcoin ETFs

Instances.input: Banks may no longer need to set aside billions of dollars in capital as they wait for collateral to be settled, thanks to a blockchain-inspired back-office platform introduced by Citi and CME Clearing. The companies partnered with Baton Systems to develop the system, which offers real-time updates on ledger collateral and eliminates the requirement for capital to be set aside to cover settlements, as well as speeding up margin funding times. The software also allows real-time transfer of cash and securities to clearing houses. Other efficiencies include reducing the need for manual intervention and reducing email traffic.
output: Blockchain-derived platform cuts back-office costs for banks

Instances.input: Ohio-based firm Root Insurance has been granted a licence to sell insurance products in the US state of Arkansas. The insurtech, which uses telematics data gathered from a smartphone app to offer personalised car insurance, recently also secured a licence to sell car insurance in Mississippi, and has a presence in nine US states. Root also plans to expand to Louisiana, Maryland, North Dakota, Montana and North Carolina.
output: Root approved to offer policies in Arkansas, Mississippi

Instances.input: Increasing numbers of Indian insurers are predicted to go public in 2018. Last year saw five insurance companies hold successful initial public offerings, including two state-run firms, which collectively raised INR450bn ($7bn). This year, however, is also expected to see some consolidation in the insurance sector, despite the merger of Max Life and Max Financial Services with HDFC Standard Life Insurance falling through.
output: Increased number of Indian insurers expected to IPO in 2018

Instances.input: US electrical company Emerson has extended the potential applications of its temperature-sensor system. The Rosemount X-well technology measures the surface temperature of pipes and uses an algorithm based on the conductive properties of the materials from which the pipe is made to work out the temperature inside. This allows users to obtain an accurate reading without having to intrude into the process or install thermowells to protect sensors. Emerson has now made it available on a new platform for users with wired networks.
output: Emerson launches surface-sensor oil pipe temperature reader

Instances.input: 3D printing could help oil and gas companies extend the life of parts that are no longer manufactured by applying additive material to a specific area that is worn, said Stephen Fitzpatrick, machining team lead at the University of Strathclyde Advanced Forming. Laser metal deposition allows the remanufacture of difficult-to-weld oil and gas components, such as those made of corrosion-resistant steels and heat-resistant super alloys, he said. Both direct energy deposition and powder bed fusion use a diverse range of metals in wire and powder form, which can be fused together using lasers, electron beams and electric arcs.
output: 3D printing can extend life of ageing oil and gas assets

Instances.input: A work flow that incorporates near-wellbore-saturation logs has helped determine whether oil wells in India's Upper Assam-Arakan Basin can be rejuvenated, according to a study carried out in old wells. It revealed that a combination of field-development plan results with pulsed neutron tool log interpretations could quickly and efficiently verify near-wellbore hydrocarbon saturations.
output: New monitoring technique could improve output from old oil wells

Instances.input: Norwegian company Fluenta has launched two devices that can measure the flow of gas through a pipeline in extreme temperatures. The ultrasonic flow transducers can work on gas mixes of 100% methane or 100% carbon dioxide, something many other gauges are unable to do. The high-temperature transducer aimed at the chemical-processing industry is able to measure gas flow at temperatures up to 250°C, while Fluenta's cryogenic transducer has been designed to function in temperatures as low as -200°C, making it ideal for the liquefied natural gas industry.
output: Fluenta unveils extreme-temperature gas-flow gauges

Instances.input: Global temperature rises of 2C above pre-industrial levels could result in over 25% of the earth’s surface becoming considerably drier, increasing the risk of drought and wildfires and threatening agriculture and biodiversity, according to new research. Restricting global warming to less than 1.5C would save two-thirds of such areas from such severe change. The study analysed projections from 27 global climate models in order to identify the regions that were most at risk, including Central America, southeast Asia, southern Africa, southern Australia and southern Europe. These regions are home to 20% of the world’s current population.
output: Global warming of 2C could render 25% of globe arid

Instances.input: UK recycling plants are already experiencing a build up of rubbish as a result of a Chinese ban on imports of plastic waste. As we reported last month, the ban, which applies to 24 kinds of solid waste, came into effect on 1 January 2018. Two-thirds of the UK’s total plastic waste exports, or over 2.7 million tonnes, have been shipped to China and Hong Kong since 2012. UK Recycling Association CEO, Simon Ellin, warned of possible chaos if councils stopped collecting recycling.
output: UK recycling plants see rubbish pile up due to Chinese ban

Instances.input: A drone delivery service, partnering Silicon Valley robotics firm Zipline with Rwanda’s health ministry, has delivered over 5,500 units of blood in the past year, reducing delivery times to remote regions from four hours to an average of 30 minutes. Zipline supplies blood to 12 regional hospitals, each of which serves half a million people. The service has reduced maternal deaths and malaria-induced anaemia, as well as limiting waste by reducing the amount of blood that hospitals need to store. The company now plans to launch the largest drone delivery network in the world in Tanzania.
output: Drones provide ‘Uber for blood’ in Rwanda

Instances.input: Pret a Manger has doubled the discount it offers on hot drinks to customers with reusable cups to 50p. The sandwich chain, along with Costa and Starbucks, has been offering a discount of 25p to such customers since 2017. The move follows other waste reduction initiatives by the company, including abandoning the use of plastic cup stoppers in inner city Pret branches. The UK discards 2.5 billion coffee cups each year, with fewer than one in 400 being recycled.
output: Pret a Manger introduces 50p discount for reusable cups

Instances.input: Iran is seeing its largest protests since 2009. They began over economic grievances but have taken on a political dimension, resulting in more than a dozen deaths and hundreds of arrests. Police stations have been attacked and  security forces are struggling to contain the uprisings. Iran is a major OPEC member and regional power but there is increasing frustration over its involvement in Syria and Iraq as it battles for regional influence to rival Saudi Arabia. Iranians want the government to create jobs -- youth unemployment reached 28.8% in 2017 -- rather than get involved in costly proxy wars.
output: Iran sees biggest protests since 2009 as economic hardships bite

Instances.input: Environmentally friendly detergents using enzymes from items including mushrooms are being developed by Danish biotechnology firm, Novozymes. Enzyme detergents, for use in washing machines and dishwashers, work at lower temperatures, require less water and use less soap from palm oil and petrochemicals than traditional alternatives. Washing machines are currently responsible for over 6% of European Union household electricity use. Novozymes has also developed a enzyme being used in China that it hopes will prevent people in that country starting to wash clothes at higher temperatures as they become wealthier, claiming this would constitute “a phenomenal sustainability story”.
output: Mushroom enzymes could reduce environmental impact of laundry

Instances.input: Tesco has faced criticism in relation to edible food waste over the Christmas period. An employee at a branch of the supermarket in Devon claimed to have been told to throw away six cages of vegetables that were still in-date on Christmas Eve. Just two days earlier, Tesco CEO, Dave Lewis, had announced a commitment that no food fit for human consumption should go to waste in UK branches by the end of February. All leading UK supermarkets, including Tesco, have pledged to reduce food waste by 20% within a decade under the government-backed initiative, the Courtauld Commitment 2025.
output: Tesco criticised for food waste after CEO’s pledge

Instances.input: The UK broke 13 clean energy records in 2017, according to data from the National Grid. The country has reduced emissions from the electricity sector by 50% since 2012, making it the fourth-cleanest European power system and the seventh cleanest in the world. In April, the UK experienced a 24-hour period of using no coal power for the first time since the Industrial Revolution. In June, nuclear, solar and wind energy generated more power in the country than coal and gas combined. Separate findings also revealed that for 90% of 2017 renewable energy sources provided more UK power than coal.
output: UK power producers broke 13 clean energy records in 2017

Instances.input: Annual migration to Europe could triple by the end of the century due to climate change, according to a study from New York’s Columbia University. The study’s author, Wolfram Schlenker, stated that even if efforts to curtail global warming succeeded, asylum applications could still rise by 25% by 2100. The research, which focused only on the impact of climate change on migration, excluding other economic and political factors, analysed asylum applications to European Union states from 103 countries between 2000 and 2014. Countries with average temperatures of 20C produced higher number of applications.
output: Climate change could triple migration to Europe by 2100

Instances.input: Spanish utility Iberdrola has secured 295 MW of wind power capacity in a Brazilian auction, which saw more than 3,841 MW of clean power supply contracts awarded. The deal will see Iberdrola's subsidiary, Neoenergia, develop and bring online nine wind farms in the state of Paraiba by January 2022, increasing Neoenergia's wind capacity to over 800 MW. The project represents Iberdrola's first major step in Brazil after merging Neoenergia with its Brazilian unit Elektro earlier this year.
output: Iberdrola awarded 295 MW of wind in Brazilian auction

Instances.input: Private equity firm GN Renewable Investments has backed the development of a 36 MW wind farm in the north of France by Nordex France. The Epine Marie Madelaine project will include a 15 year service agreement and 12 Nordex N117-3000 turbines. The project, due to be operational by September 2018, is the second French order for a 36 MW project using Nordex turbines in the past two days.
output: PE firm GN Renewable chooses Nordex for French wind project

Instances.input: Shell has acquired the UK's largest independent energy provider, First Utility, for an undisclosed sum. The energy provider, which also supplies broadband services and smart home energy management, will continue to operate as an independent entity under Shell's "New Energies" division. First Utility CFO Darren Braham said the move will help the provider to "capitalise on all the opportunities provided by digitalisation, decarbonisation and the move to battery technology and electric vehicles", whilst continuing to disrupt the Big Six-dominated UK retail-energy market.
output: Shell acquires UK's First Utility in retail power push

Instances.input: Canadian Solar will begin construction of a 112 MW solar PV project in Pernambuco, Brazil following a December 2017 auction. More than 310,000 PV panels will be provided to the project by Canadian Solar and approximately 255,743 MWh of electricity per year is expected to be generated from the project. Canadian Solar's has won capacity in all of Brazil's federal PV auction to date and has more than 1 GW of power purchase agreements in place across South America.
output: Canadian Solar wins 112 MW solar PV project in Brazil

Instances.input: Insurers are utilising satellite and sensor technology to levy data analytics for determining risk. Information mining could be the largest disruptor in the insurance industry, changing pricing, claims and payments. Among companies making use of the technology, QBE Insurance Group is using satellite readings to track activity such as shipping movements. Elsewhere, Australia's IAG has been testing an app offering drivers rewards when they don't use their smartphone while driving. AIA Group is also using data from tech wearables to determine life-insurance pricing.
output: Insurers adopt satellite technology for data insights

Instances.input: Goldwind Australia has secured nearly AUD700m ($548m) in financing for its 530 MW Stockyard Hill wind project in Victoria, led by the National Australia Bank and a consortium of international investment banks. Goldwind bought the Stockyard Hill project from Origin Energy for AUD110m and secured a power purchase agreement to sell the plant's output to Origin at below AUD60/MWh. Construction activities will begin in Q1 2018 and the project's plant services will be delivered via a joint venture between Canadian engineering group SNC-Lavalin and Australia’s WBHO Infrastructure.
output: Goldwind raises AUD700m for 530 MW Australian wind project

Instances.input: A 3 MW solar power plant being built in New Mexico is to sell its power at less than $45/MWh, in what The Rocky Mountain Institute believes to be the lowest reported contract for distributed solar photovoltaic (PV) energy in the US. The plant, which is owned by SoCore Energy, will sell power to non-profit rural electric cooperative Otero County Electric Cooperative (OCEC) under a 25 year contract. OCEC will receive the renewable energy credits from the project.
output: New Mexico solar park to sell cheapest PV energy in US

Instances.input: The Dutch government has received an undisclosed number of bids for its unsubsidised offshore wind tender, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy has announced. Applicants are currently being reviewed on the merits of timely construction, the quantity of energy generation and sound risk management. The eventual winner will be required to bring the wind farm online by 2022. "If these applications do indeed result in an offshore wind farm being constructed without any subsidy, it will be a huge breakthrough," said economic affairs minister Eric Wiebes.
output: Subsidy-free Dutch offshore wind project tender receives bids

Instances.input: China's National Energy Administration is to set up a new photovoltaic (PV) monitoring system to help channel funding into regions that harness solar power most efficiently. Curtailment -- production of energy that can't be used -- has been a significant roadblock for the development of PV in China, with Bloomberg New Energy Finance estimating that approximately 3.28 TWh of solar capacity was wasted in 2016. The new system will advise prospective developers using data regarding site conditions, regional subsidy levels and local government support and will help shape the establishment of the government's yearly PV installation quotas.
output: China to monitor PV efficiency to help guide regional investment

Instances.input: A new scheme to promote rooftop solar-panel installations in Israel is hoped to bring online about 1.6 GW of new solar capacity and help the country reach its 10% renewable energy goal by 2020. The scheme would allow photovoltaic (PV) installations up to 15 KW to be eligible to access the net metering scheme or to apply for a 25-year feed-in tariff (FIT) of 0.39 ILS/KWH ($0.111/KWH). Meanwhile, PV installations ranging from 15 KW to 50 KW will be supported with a 25-year FIT of 0.33 ILS/KWH.
output: Israel mulls solar rooftop scheme to reach 2020 renewables target

Instances.input: The solar investment tax credit (ITC) has survived a major round of tax reform following fears of an effective shortening of the ITC down to four years. However, the broader objectives of the tax reforms are likely to have a negative effect on the demand for tax credits, as US corporation tax looks set to be reduced from 35% to 21%. President and CEO of the Solar Energy Industries Association, Abigail Ross Hopper, said: "This is a great victory for the solar industry and its 260,000 American workers".
output: Solar tax credits survive tax reform in US

Instances.input: Austin's City Council has approved a renewable energy agreement with Austin Energy, which will boost Austin’s solar capacity to nearly 800MW. The newly approved contract, which allows Austin Energy to purchase power generated by a new 150 MW PV project as well as an additional 30 MW provided the economics are favourable, is expected to make Austin Energy 51% renewable by 2020. Jackie Sargent, Austin Energy's general manager, said that the new purchase power agreement demonstrated the utility's commitment to "economic and environmental leadership” for the Austin community.
output: Austin green lights 150 MW solar project

Instances.input: Investment firm Foresight Group has begun building its second unsubsidised PV asset on the Iberian Peninsula, a 3.9 MW solar project in Spain's Las Torres de Cotillas municipality. The project, which will deliver 7 GWh of green electricity per year, is due for grid connection in 2019 and is being developed by Spanish firm Solarig Global Services. The electricity generated will be sold under a long-term power purchase agreement (PPA) with the utility Energya-VM, an arrangement that Foresight director Carlos Rey said establishes "an exciting new precedent in the Spanish solar industry".
output: Foresight Group begins building unsubsidised solar in Spain

Instances.input: Turkish EPC company Asunim has finalised the development of a 40.3 MW PV project by successfully connecting the site to Turkey's national grid. The project consists of two installations situated alongside one another in Maisa, with each installation representing generation capabilities of 19.7 MW and 20.6 MW respectively. Ongoing operational and maintenance duties on the project's JinkoSolar solar modules and REFUsol 40 KW string inverters will now be carried out by Maxima Energy, which is an affiliate of Asunim.
output: 40.3 MW PV project connected to Turkish grid

Instances.input: Sweden's Vattenfall will supply 1.5 TWh of electricity to Dutch paint and speciality chemicals firm, AkzoNobel, to help it meet its 2050 carbon target. The Swedish state-owned utility will supply power for AkzoNobel's chemical production sites in Delfzijl, Hengelo and Rotterdam. It will also manage energy use fluctuations for better cost control and provide AkzoNobel with access to the power market through its trading operations. Vattenfall has provided power to the Dutch company's facilities in Sweden and Finland since the start of 2017.
output: Vattenfall to deliver 1.5 TWh of power to AkzoNobel

Instances.input: Global investment manager AMP Capital has invested in the independent French power developer Neoen with mezzanine funding of €245m ($295m). Neoen, which is active in global solar markets including Australia and Argentina, will use the funding for a 1.6 GW portfolio of onshore wind and solar PV assets in France and Australia, according to AMP Capital. Neoen other projects include a Tesla partnership to install a 129 MWh lithium-ion battery in Australia and a 200 MW solar plant in Argentina.
output: AMP Capital invests €245m in French power developer Neoen

Instances.input: China has opened a 2 km solar expressway, joining France and the Netherlands in testing the technology. The road is made up of an insulating layer on the bottom, photovoltaic panels in the middle and transparent concrete on top. The solar panels cover 5,875 sq metres and can generate 1 million kWh of power a year, enough to meet the energy demands of about 800 homes, the developer said. The cost of the solar road was about $458 per sq metre, compared with about $260 per sq metre for rooftop solar and about $200 per sq metre for asphalt road.
output: China opens 2 km solar highway

Instances.input: Peruvian renewable energy company Enel Green Power Peru has been lent $150m by the European Investment Bank (EIB) for a wind farm and a solar power plant with combined capacity of 312 MW. The projects are slated for completion in the first half of 2018.
output: EIB lends $150m for Peruvian wind, solar projects

Instances.input: Installed wind power capacity across Europe will hit 302 GW by 2026, according to Make consultants. Make's Europe Wind Power Outlook 2017 report predicted that new European capacity installed over the next decade will reach 161 GW, including 39 GW offshore, with the largest advances being made in Germany, the UK and France. The long-term prospects for eastern and southern European markets are also positive, despite regulatory hurdles and low power demand, the report added.
output: Europe on target for 161 GW growth in wind energy by 2026

Instances.input: Italy is aiming to produce 40 TWh per year of wind power by 2030 as part of its national energy strategy. The recently approved Strategia Energetica Nazionale calls for renewables to make up 28% of total energy consumption in 2030, up from 17.5% in 2015. The 40 TWh wind-energy target is more than double the 15 TWh produced three years ago. The strategy also highlights the need for repowering wind farms and simplifying the authorisation process for the country to meet its national renewables goals.
output: Italy aims to double annual wind power output to 40 TWh by 2030

Instances.input: A 500 MW wind power auction in the Indian state of Gujarat has seen tariffs tumble. Wind prices fell to INR2.43/kWh ($38.88/MWh) by the time bidding closed on 21 December, undercutting even the lowest tariff of INR2.44/kWh from earlier in the year. Actis-backed Spring Energy took the highest allocation with 197.5 MW, while Verdant Energy secured 100 MW.
output: Gujurat wind-power auction sees significant drop in tariffs

Instances.input: China's Yingli Green Energy saw its net loss widen to CNY2.3bn ($352m) in Q3 2017, up from CNY335.4m in the same period in 2016. It also reported a 48% drop in quarterly photovoltaic (PV) module shipments to 597.7 MW. CEO Liansheng Miao said the decrease in shipments on the previous quarter was due to lower demand as Yingli tried to balance shipment volumes with operating cash flows. It expects to ship 700 MW to 800 MW of PV panels in 4Q, and raised its full-year guidance for shipments to between 2.8 GW and 2.9 GW.
output: World's biggest solar panel maker posts $355m Q3 loss

Instances.input: The US Department of Energy (DOE) has authorised $12m in further funding for solar forecasting technologies. The money will be split between eight projects which aim to enhance forecasting technologies, advance variability management and improve grid reliability and resilience. Some $1.8m of the funding will go to the Electric Power Research Institute in Tennessee, towards a scheme developing better probabilistic solar and net load predictions. Other winners include the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, the University of Arizona and John Hopkins University.
output: US DOE approves $12m funding for solar technologies

Instances.input: The Solar Energy Research Institute of Singapore (SERIS) has achieved a 21.5% average efficiency for its printed silicon solar cell technology. The bifacial MonoPoly technology can be used on both n-type and p-type wafers, and aims to offer similar efficiency levels to modern passivated emitter and rear cell (PERC) concepts, at lower cost. SERIS will now seek to improve the cells' efficiency and expects to reach the 23% mark though improvements to materials and the production process.
output: Singapore achieves 21.5% efficiency from printed solar cell

Instances.input: Oxford PV has secured €15m ($18m) from the European Investment Bank (EIB) to help take its perovskite solar cell technology into commercial production. Oxford PV Germany, a subsidiary of the UK-based developer, received the funding from InnovFin Energy Demonstration Projects, which supports European action on climate change. It will help the company build its perovskite on silicon tandem solar cell technology into an industrial-scale process in collaboration with its joint development partner, a large-scale solar cell and module manufacturer.
output: EIB awards Oxford PV €15m to build perovskite solar plant

Instances.input: Vortex has sold its 45% share in Vortex Solar Investments to Malaysia's second biggest pension fund, Kumpulan Wang Persaraan (KWAP). Vortex will keep a 5% stake in its former SunEdison-built solar portfolio in the UK as part of the deal, valued at £67.5m ($91m). Vortex and its parent firm, EFG Hermes, acquired TerraForm Power's 365 MW portfolio at the start of 2017.
output: Vortex sells stake in solar portfolio to Malaysian pension fund

Instances.input: California could meet all its energy needs without building photovoltaic (PV) panels on productive farmland, according to University of California researchers. The scientists examined four alternatives for deploying solar: built environments such as urban rooftops, building facades and walls; land too salty for crops; contaminated land, and water reservoirs for floating solar facilities. Looking at the state's Central Valley for calculations, the researchers forecast that the four land types could contain PV installations producing 17,348 TWh/year or more, which is approximately 13 times the state's expected yearly power demand up to 2025.
output: California can meet power needs without solar on farmland

Instances.input: Hanergy is teaming up with a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) group to develop thin-film solar technology for cars and homes. Among other projects, Hanergy and BAIC BJEV -- the EV unit of Beijing Automotive Group -- will work together on home- and vehicle-integrated solar panels and charging units. Rooftop solar could provide auxiliary, and possibly even main, power for a vehicle, in addition to charging, Hanergy claims. The pair will also add rooftop solar to BAIC BJEV's car factories. In addition, the partnership will explore the use of thin-film solar for agriculture and poverty alleviation.
output: Hanergy partners with Chinese EV group for solar-run cars, homes

Instances.input: Solar Frontier has achieved a world record thin-film solar cell efficiency of 22.9%, the company said. The result, achieved on a 1 sq cm cell, was 0.3% higher than a previous record set by German research centre ZSW and verified by Japan's National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology. The cell used copper, indium and selenium (CIS) technology with improvements from "absorber engineering and enhanced surface treatment of the absorber layer", Solar Frontier said. It was developed in partnership with Japan's National Research and Development Agency's New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organisation.
output: Solar Frontier achieves thin-film efficiency record

Instances.input: The Indian government has proposed direct financial support of INR110bn ($1.7bn) for its domestic solar manufacturers to make them more competitive globally. The country's Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) also suggested 12 GW of public sector tenders to include locally-sourced solar equipment. Other plans included encouraging production of ingots, polysilicon and wafers from scratch. The ideas were included in a range of proposals released by the MNRE in December.
output: India moots $1.7bn support for local solar firms

Instances.input: The Solar Energy Corporation of India (SECI) has launched an expression of interest (EOI) for 10 GW of floating solar capacity. It has also sought interest in building 20 GW of local manufacturing capacity. Vinay Rustagi, managing director of Bridge to India, said: "Both the ideas are pretty radical in our view. The timelines and the capacities indicated are also highly unrealistic.” However, India has expanded its installed solar capacity at a rapid rate in recent years, and there are challenges in buying land for solar projects, so floating solar may become an increasingly attractive option.
output: SECI issues 10 GW Indian floating solar tender

Instances.input: Clean Focus Yield and its associates have acquired Greenskies Renewable Energy, making it the largest commercial and industrial solar operator in the US. Clean Focus CEO Stanley Chin said the deal would provide new opportunities for customers and financing partners. Connecticut-based Greenskies will continue to operate under its own brand and management, and expects to broaden its corporate and retail client base. It also plans to expand its 350 MW project pipeline into new areas such as community solar, hospitals and schools.
output: Clean Focus becomes largest commercial solar operator in US

Instances.input: The European Investment Bank (EIB) and Yes Bank have teamed up to provide $400m in funding for Indian renewables. The EIB will provide a 15-year $200m loan as part of the co-financing initiative, with the remainder coming from Indian private sector financier Yes Bank, project promoters and other financial institutions. Eligible solar schemes have already been identified in the states of Karnataka, Maharashtra, Rajasthan and Telangana, and other solar and wind projects are under consideration.
output: EIB and Yes Bank pledge $400m for Indian renewables

Instances.input: US fast food restaurant CaliBurger is trialling a new self-serve kiosk which uses AI and facial-recognition technology to allow customers to place orders, pay and log in to a rewards account. The facial recognition software will also enable customers to store their orders so that when they next visit, they can order their food just by looking in to the camera. The technology and security is developed and overseen by NEC Corporation. The sole test kiosk currently in operation can be found in the Pasadena CaliBurger store, with global rollouts pending a successful trial.
output: CaliBurger to use facial recognition to take food orders

Instances.input: The New York Stock Exchange has sought Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) approval to list two bitcoin-linked exchange-traded funds managed by ProShares. The ETF provider has also filed a request with the SEC to launch the products, which give investors exposure to the cryptocurrency via futures contracts. The funds -- one of which allows investors to bet against the cryptocurrency -- would invest in benchmark futures contracts, though with the option to invest outside of the benchmark.
output: NYSE, ProShares seek SEC approval to list bitcoin futures ETFs

Instances.input: Following a recent funding round, female-centric robo-adviser Ellevest has introduced a new pricing structure. The platform will now be split into three levels of service. The first, costing 25 bps, gives clients access to algorithmic portfolio creation and advice from human advisers via digital communications. For 50 bps and a minimum investment of $50,000, clients can gain access to personalised goal-planning advice from a certified adviser, as well as information such as career advice. Lastly, the firm is offering a private wealth management service for clients with more than $1m in investing assets.
output: Robo-adviser for women Ellevest introduces tiered pricing system

Instances.input: JPMorgan Chase is planning to introduce a low-cost wealth management tool in 2018. The firm will allow a sub-section of clients to access the tool in March, with a full launch planned for the middle of the year. The platform, dubbed JPMorgan Digital Investing, will ask clients questions to determine their investment goals and risk appetite. Clients will then be able to access a model portfolio constructed using exchange-traded funds.
output: JPMorgan to introduce low-cost robo-adviser in 2018

Instances.input: Aviva's Chinese affiliate is to harness the power of artificial intelligence (AI) to focus marketing and improve customer experiences in a big-data project with technology giant Tencent. The two will open a lab to analyse the insurer's business data. It's all part of UK-based Aviva's investment programme in its global digital operations, which has seen it spend about $134m a year since 2014.
output: Aviva, Tencent partner in big-data lab for Chinese AI push

Instances.input: Chinese visitors to the UK can now use WeChat, China's "app for everything", to buy their souvenirs. WeChat Pay was made available for point-of-sale locations in the UK through a partnership with British fintech firm SafeCharge, beginning in November 2017. According to VisitBritain, Chinese tourists spent £513 million in Britain last year.
output: WeChat mobile payments arrive in United Kingdom

Instances.input: India-based insurtech start-up Toffee is looking to crack the millennial market by selling micro-insurance, offering policies only when a customer requires them. For example, with only 6%-7% of Indians taking out comprehensive health insurance, Toffee offers coverage for specific diseases, such as Dengue fever, co-founder Nishant Jain said. Toffee is also aiming to speed up the claims process in India, reducing it from the typical two-to-three weeks to as little as two days, he said.
output: Toffee slices, dices insurance to crack Indian millennial market

Instances.input: Having all but evaporated in the past 18 months, mergers and acquisitions could make a comeback within the reinsurance space during 2018, according to Clyde & Co. After record catastrophe losses in 2017, several company balance sheets could be under pressure, potentially opening the door to more M&A. Equally, Clyde & Co argues pricing pressure could decrease due to rate hikes in loss-impacted lines of business. This could free up firms to focus on M&A. The rise of insurtech also may create buying opportunities for incumbent reinsurers, the company said.
output: Reinsurance M&A to pick up after catastrophe losses: Clyde & Co

Instances.input: Major companies, including Amazon, Boohoo, Groupon and TK Maxx, sold products in the UK containing real animal fur that they advertised as synthetic, according to tests conducted by charity Humane Society International and Sky News. The investigation led campaigners to call for a ban on fur imports. Although fur farming was prohibited in the UK in 2003, such imports remain legal. TK Maxx is offering refunds to affected customers, while Groupon and Boohoo are reviewing their procedures. Amazon said that it could delete the accounts of sellers failing to meet the company’s guidelines.
output: Leading UK retailers selling real fur as fake

Instances.input: Huawei, the Chinese smartphone giant, has agreed a deal with Nokia for access to its intellectual property [IP] portfolio. Details of the agreement are yet to emerge, but it is set to last for several years. The chief legal officer at Nokia, Maria Varsellona, said the Finnish telecoms firm was “delighted to welcome" Huawei to "our family of patent licensees." Tighter IP laws have been seen as constraining Huawei's expansion into more developed regions like Europe. In the third quarter of 2017, Nokia's licensing arm brought in 8% of its revenue.
output: Nokia and Huawei sign patent license agreement

Instances.input: UK agency workers are collectively paid £400m ($534m) less than their permanent peers, according to research by charity the Resolution Foundation. Temporary admin staff experience an average pay gap of £990 annually. The average individual loss for the country’s 800,000 agency workers is £500 per year, up from £430 in 2016. After three months with the same employer, agency workers are legally expected to have the same pay as full-time colleagues. However, 85% were found to have a pay deficit. “Swedish derogation” contracts, which offer pay between assignments, are used to allow workers to sign away equal pay rights.
output: UK agency workers paid £400m less than peers

Instances.input: Champagne company Moët has launched a game on social media platform Snapchat, aimed at over 25s, despite wider industry concerns regarding Snapchat's age-filtering capabilities. Both Heineken and William Grant & Sons have previously cited difficulties in verifying recipient ages on Snapchat. Moët's marketing director, Ngo Isaac, believes that the issue other firms experience is with their targeting, arguing that they "just take a piece of content from other platforms and amplify it through Snapchat".
output: Moet breaks trend for alcohol companies with Snapchat game

Instances.input: Digital advertising firms PageFair and AppNexus are addressing publishers and adtech firms' needs as implementation of the EU's General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR) approaches. PageFair's Perimeter, a "regulatory firewall", will allow publishers to monetise websites without using users' personal data by blocking non-GDPR-compliant firms from being included in the adtech chain. AppNexus has created the role of vice-president of strategic and regulatory affairs to help its partners change their business plans to accommodate the new regulations. It is also offering an open-source tool to help firms with compliance.
output: PageFair and AppNexus help to make partners GDPR compliant

Instances.input: Google is using artificial intelligence (AI) technology to predict which images humans will find more enjoyable to look at. Researchers at the company have devised a system called neural image assessment, which uses computer learning and a 10-point rating scale to determine how likely particular images will be preferred by humans. The technology could be used to select the best images from a batch taken at the same time, or to optimise the settings for an image to make it more attractive.
output: Google's AI predicts whether a human will like certain images

Instances.input: Inside Real Estate has acquired cloud commission management provider BrokerSumo, growing the Inside Real Estates' kvCORE platform into financial and accounting systems. Clients will be able to run their marketing and sales automatically through kvCORE, and be able to track and analyse transactions through financial outcomes. BrokerSumo offers commission calculation management, transaction payments, reporting and agent onboarding and billing through its product.
output: Inside Real Estate buys commission management provider BrokerSumo

Instances.input: Ad buyers looking to advertise on Amazon report their frustrations with Amazon's client services teams in increasing numbers. Agency sources have spoken of their experiences "stalking" Amazon for a year before making headway, and even then, one anonymous source has said that Amazon's service is so murkily structured that "you never have a holistic idea of what’s going on”. PMG's digital strategy EVP Price Glomski argues that to retain agency buy-in, Amazon needs to "provide optics to performance on a daily and hourly level", as competitors Google and Facebook continue providing more transparent client services.
output: Ad buyers find Amazon client services hard to work with

Instances.input: High antibiotic use is concentrated in a small percentage of UK dairy farms, according to new research. The study, which investigated 358 farms, housing 7% of England’s dairy cows, found that although most farms surveyed used lower levels of antibiotics than UK livestock averages, 25% of farms were using 52% of the drugs. The researchers could not identify the reasons for such concentrated high use, but said that studying such farms could reduce the use of antibiotics in the sector. Use of antibiotics in farming is causing growing concern about antibiotic resistance and resultant threats to human health.
output: Antibiotic use concentrated in small number of UK dairy farms

Instances.input: LG Electronics has launched a new brand for its work on artificial intelligence (AI) technology. The South Korean company will market all its future AI products and services under the ThinQ name, incorporating the new logo on products including those which use its other product brands Dios, Tromm and Whisen. LG established an AI laboratory earlier this year, and has been working on building AI home appliances and wireless infrastructure. As well as being compatible with Amazon's Alexa, the technology also makes use of LG's own proprietary system, DeepThinQ.
output: LG ventures into AI market with ThinQ

Instances.input: Apple has revealed that it deliberately slows down older iPhones, but says this is due to the diminishing performance of the phones’ batteries and the need to avoid sudden shut-downs. Some customers have suspected that the company slows older models in order to encourage customers to upgrade. The revelation follows the sharing by a customer of performance tests on Reddit. Tech website Geekbench then performed further tests, which suggested that some phones had indeed been deliberately slowed.
output: Apple confirms deliberate slowing of older iPhones

Instances.input: Michelle Kunken has been appointed executive creative director (ECD) at Saatchi & Saatchi New York, reporting to chief creative officer Javier Campopiano. Fast-growing agency DNA has promoted Chris Witherspoon to president and the newly created position of chief growth officer, while at GroupM's Mindshare, M K Machaiah has been named as chief innovation officer of South Asia.
output: Saatchi & Saatchi, DNA and Mindshare make notable appointments

Instances.input: Privately funded aerospace manufacturer and spaceflight services firm Blue Origins New Shepard launch system is approximately one year from launching a programme of manned spaceflights. The system has been used for a test flight with the company's Crew Capsule 2.0 to suborbital space. The company will be competing against Boeing and SpaceX, which both plan to launch manned test flights next year.
output: Blue Origin steps up rocket tests for space tourism

Instances.input: India's economy is predicted to reach $10tn by 2035, with artificial intelligence expected to make up $975bn of the gross domestic product, according to a report by Accenture. The US company said it had based its results on a study of India's universities and businesses from start-ups to large companies, as well as policymakers and multi-stakeholder partnerships, and said India needed to come up with a "multi-stakeholder action plan".
output: AI to add $957bn to India's GDP by 2035: Accenture

Instances.input: From Q1 next year, users of JPMorgan's Chase Freedom wallet will be able to earn rewards when using Apple Pay, Android Pay and Samsung Pay, in a move aimed at increasing adoption of its mobile wallet. The US mobile wallet market underperformed in 2017, and Chase Freedom struggled in particular, with just 6% of shoppers adopting it, despite a $100m investment. However, by taking a leaf out of Samsung's book, whose specific rewards programme led to a huge increase in engagement, JPMorgan hopes to encourage use of the wallet.
output: JPMorgan Chase encouraging mobile wallet use

Instances.input: Glencore faces investigation by the Swiss attorney general over whether its acquisition of a copper mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) involved a failure to prevent illegal practices. Human rights group Public Eye lodged a criminal complaint following information revealed in the Paradise Papers, leaked earlier this year from offshore law firm Appleby. The papers revealed Glencore lent $45m to a company belonging to diamond merchant Dan Gertler after using him to help arrange a joint venture with DRC state-controlled mining group Gécamines, on the proviso the loan was immediately repayable if the contract was not granted.
output: Glencore faces criminal complaint after Paradise Papers claims

Instances.input: UK Communities Secretary Sajid Javid has unveiled a series of measures to tackle unfair practices in the leasehold sector, following an overwhelmingly positive public response to a recent government consultation. Javid said the new rules, covering England only, will include preventing the sale of new build leasehold houses, except in instances of shared ownership. Ground rents on new long leases will be set at zero, and freeholders will have the same rights as leaseholders to challenge service charges they deem unfair.
output: Leaseholds to be banned on most new build homes in England

Instances.input: Increasing numbers of online sex workers are tuning to digital currencies to facilitate customer payments, according to MarketWatch. It spoke to a financial dominatrix called Theodora, who said she asks her clients to pay in crypto because peer-to-peer payment site PayPal has blacklisted sex workers. Theodora also revealed she used customers to mine digital currency for her in a crypto "slave farm".
output: Financial dominatrix gets her clients to mine cryptos

Instances.input: Some managers of direct lending funds have been lowering hurdle rates for their products in recent fundraising rounds. The move effectively boosts overall fees, according to consultancy Bfinance. The consultancy added, however, many managers are yet to take the step, which would be unpopular with limited partners in the funds. The consultancy said hurdle rates within the direct lending market have not been too high in recent years, if anything slight too low in some cases. Hurdle rates are the point at which performance and other fees start being applied to funds.
output: Direct lending managers plan on lowering hurdle rates

Instances.input: General Motors has launched Marketplace, the first automotive commerce platform that allows customers to make on-demand orders and reservations using their vehicle's dashboard. Drivers will be able to reserve tables for dinner, search for the nearest filling station and order food with Buick, GMC, Cadillac and Chevrolet cars. Drivers will also be able to shop for oil change discounts, GM accessory deals and Wi-Fi data. The feature will be offered over 12 to 18 months to about four million car owners in the US, and is intended to be used while driving. Brand partners include Starbucks and Dunkin' Donuts.
output: GM car owners can order and pay for items while driving

Instances.input: 3D digital printing company Carbon has closed a $200m series D funding round, led by Baillie Gifford, Fidelity Management & Research Company, Sequoia Capital, Hydra Ventures and GE Ventures. Carbon offers the manufacturing industry hardware, software and "molecular science" support. The company is most famous for its 3D-printed show sole for Adidas' Futurecraft 4D shoes; Adidas has invested in the company through its venture capital arm, Hydra Ventures. Carbon had previously raised approximately $220m in funding, with the new capital due to be used for scaling its tech for manufacturing.
output: Digital 3D printing company Carbon raises $200m in first round

Instances.input: UK drivers may soon be permitted to park cars using remote control if proposals to a consultation on updating the Highway Code are accepted. The new laws indicate a step towards "level 5" driverless vehicles that don't require a human driver and may not even be equipped with a steering wheel or pedals. The UK’s Centre for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles determines level 5 to be "hands off, eyes off" driving. Remote control parking could be particularly useful for drivers with mobility issues. The consultation also covers the use of motorway assistance technology.
output: UK close to legalising remote control car parking

Instances.input: NASA has aims to send a space shuttle to adjacent star system Alpha Centauri by the year 2069, on the 100th anniversary of the moon landing. The star system, 24.9 trillion miles away from Earth, will be searched for signs of life, inspired by the discovery of an Earth-type planet orbiting the star Proxima Centauri last year. "Proxima" has mild enough temperatures to sustain liquid surface water, which could indicate the ability to sustain life. Any travel would have to be completed at a minimum speed of 30 million metres per second, or 10% of the speed of light.
output: NASA sets 2069 date to reach neighbouring solar system

Instances.input: Digital marketers should consider Bing as an alternative to Google, given it is the second largest search engine and reaches one in three people undertaking searches, according to Paul Korber, Marin Software's head of customer success in the Asia-Pacific region. Bing Ads can be synchronised with Google AdWords and can import campaigns directly from it. Bing receives 6.2 billion searches a month, offering advertisers the chance to target a wider audience by combining their advertising with Google. Around 72% of businesses plan to increase their investments with Google next year and 36% plan to do the same with Bing.
output: Bing should not be overlooked by advertisers: opinion

Instances.input: Results from scientific modelling carried out by Oxford University have shown that a significant proportion of Mars' water resources could be locked within rock structures. "The results revealed that the basalt rocks on Mars can hold approximately 25% more water than those on Earth, and as a result drew the water from the Martian surface into its interior", said the scientists. Releasing the water now would require melting the rock, as "It is not liquid anymore but physically bound in the mineral", according to the study's co-author John Wade.
output: Mars' porous rocks may be where its missing water is hiding

Instances.input: Evidence that life existed on Earth much earlier than previously thought could indicate a greater likelihood of life on other planets. Scientists from the Universities of California and Wisconsin have published research claiming that microscopic fossils found in Western Australia show evidence of life 3.5 billion years ago. These include organisms which use methane to exist, and others which can live in environments with light but no oxygen. The ability for life to develop in such inhospitable conditions makes it more likely life could be found on Mars or other planets, they say.
output: 3.5 billion-year-old fossil indicates alien lifeforms on earth

Instances.input: Uber drivers in Manitoba are set to pay significantly less for their insurance coverage than taxi drivers in the central Canadian province. According to proposals from Manitoba Public Insurance, Uber contractors can expect rates that are roughly a quarter of those paid by taxi drivers, who pay about CAD10,000 a year ($7,795) for insurance coverage. Taxi drivers who opt to work within an allocated time window will also pay lower rates under the proposal.
output: Canadian Uber drivers to pay less for insurance than taxi drivers

Instances.input: New York-based insurtech Lemonade has been granted permission to operate in Arkansas. The firm has been green-lighted to sell property, casualty and marine coverage in the state. Lemonade will initially be restricted to offering renters insurance in this market.
output: Insurtech Lemonade approved to operate in Arkansas

Instances.input: New Zealand homeowners are being urged to check their insurance policies provide adequate cover when renting out their properties on Airbnb. The country's Insurance and Financial Services Ombudsman, Karen Stevens, has called on hosts to notify their insurers to ensure their standard cover will protect them and any guests. Stevens also suggested property owners charge a refundable deposit, and familiarise themselves with Airbnb's host guarantee, which covers up to $1m should a claim be required.
output: NZ regulator warns of Airbnb insurance risk

Instances.input: Last year saw some of the biggest funding deals in agtech, with Indigo Agriculture's record-breaking $203m Series D topping a list compiled by agfundernews.com. In second place was a $200m investment for vertical farmer Plenty, followed by Chinese outfit Maihoulang's Series A injection of $150m and Uptake's $117m Series D. Farmers Business Network received $110m in a Series D round, followed by the $100m collaboration between Bayer and Ginkgo Bioworks. Produce Pay secured $70m in Series A funds and debt, 3D Robotics raised $53m, and Protix Biosystems and Orbital Insight both garnered $50m.
output: Indigo Ag, Maihoulang top 2017 agriculture tech finding deals

Instances.input: Social Security was initiated in 1935, being signed into law by President Franklin D. Roosevelt to offer Americans an income after their retirement. However, this program has been greatly reduced. Despite a minor increase in Social Security payment due to launch in January 2018, the subsequent increases in Medicare Part B and Part D insurance premiums will offset this rise, leading to a 2 percent cost of living increase for many Social Security recipients.  Medicare premiums are deducted from Social Security payments, meaning that an increase for both services negates any positive effect. The increase may cause difficulties for retirees, and cause resentment following around 45 years of payments into the service. The proposed tax reform, however, may only exacerbate the situation, as Congress considers making cuts to Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid in 2018. With rising rents and food prices, these cuts may significantly worsen living situations. Medicare Part A deductibles are already due to increase in 2018, and Medicare Part B deductibles have already risen steadily year on year. The  Federal Reserve has also just increased interest rates, leading to higher costs on car loans, mortgages and bank loans. The tax cut proposal will likely only benefit the rich or corporations, and will increase the national debt, with the plan being to finance the move with cuts to “entitlements”, or those programs that aid the poor.
output: The Social Security cost-of-living increase is a cruel fraud

Instances.input: The cost of rocket missions by US company SpaceX could be reduced by around $5m if it is successful in plans to make more of the launch vehicle reusable and the firm has been developing technology that would enable it to recover the discarded payload fairing, a major part of the its rocket. An elaborate mechanism with claw-like appendages has recently been seen on a ship chartered by SpaceX off the west coast of the US, and is thought to be being prepared for a fairing recovery attempt after a planned Falcon 9 rocket launch.
output: SpaceX recovery vessel could reduce cost of each rocket by $5m

Instances.input: Smaller agencies approach the new year with increased momentum as the media transparency crisis envelops larger agencies and advertiser spend on independents increases. Research firm Comvergence tracked media billings from 21 markets over the first nine months of 2017 and found that $2.8bn had been assigned to independent agencies. In addition, 16 of the 42 accounts analysed in the year to June moved to an independent agency. This year smaller agencies won large advertiser contracts, with The7stars taking on Capital One and Deliveroo and OMD working with Barclays, with their "open, transparent models” credited as the reason for their success.
output: Media transparency fallout helps smaller agencies win accounts

Instances.input: Pictures of SpaceX's Falcon Heavy rocket being prepared for launch have been released by the company's founder, Elon Musk. The entrepreneur posted the photos on Twitter from the company's hangar at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The private space exploration company is planning to launch the reusable rocket next month on its maiden flight and said it is the most powerful US rocket since the Saturn V moon rocket. It has 27 engines and can carry a 57-tonne payload. Musk acknowledged there was a significant risk the launch might not go according to plan.
output: Musk tweets photos of Falcon Heavy rocket before its first launch

Instances.input: University of South Wales (UNSW) researchers may have found a solution to making quantum computing as widespread as mobile phones. They've devised a silicon microprocessor chip that can be made using many standard industry parts but still carry out the vast amount of tasks of quantum computers that currently fill entire rooms. It can process millions of quantum bits (qubits) of data, but only requires the on/off facilities of standard microprocessors.
output: New chip could make quantum computing as ubiquitous as mobiles

Instances.input: Cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase has suspended bitcoin cash transactions just minutes after it began allowing trading in the bitcoin spinoff after signs of insider trading emerged. Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong said his employees were repeatedly warned to keep the launch of bitcoin cash trading a secret; however, in the hours before the launch announcement the price of bitcoin cash began to rise on other exchanges. Since freezing trading Armstrong said: "If we find evidence of any employee or contractor violating our policies – directly or indirectly – I will not hesitate to terminate the employee immediately and take appropriate legal action."
output: Coinbase temporarily freezes bitcoin cash after blatant insider trading

Instances.input: The Trump administration has reaffirmed the United States's view that outer space does not have the legal status of "global commons" or of being a public good. The head of the US National Space Council, Scott Pace, made the comment as he outlined the Trump administration's plans to incentivise private investment in space exploration. Trump has recently refocused NASA on returning to the moon, while a range of private companies and other countries also seek to land robots there. China is planning a manned mission by 2036, raising the prospect of a new "space race" with the US.
output: Space is not a 'global commons', says Trump official

Instances.input: A Norwegian technology start-up has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system capable of helping to optimise oil and gas production in real time. Solution Seeker created the bespoke system after it found existing machine-learning algorithms were unable to cope with the constantly changing dynamics of oil production. The new model uses the company's own algorithms for data analysis and adapts to changing operational conditions with limited need for human intervention. It has been described by the company as a "significant breakthrough" and will be applied in a number of oilfields early next year.
output: Solution Seeker's bespoke AI optimises oil and gas production

Instances.input: Rating giant Moody's has signed a data licensing agreement with, and invested in, New York-based firm CompStak. The deal enables Moody's to use CompStak's aggregated lease comparable data to help it assess commercial property risk and provide more accurate ratings for commercial mortgage-backed securities. The two companies are also working on products that use broad datasets to enable customers to gain a greater understanding of markets, according to Michael Mandel, CompStak's CEO.
output: Moody's uses CompStak data to assess property deals risk

Instances.input: Predictive AI firm One Concern has just closed a $20m funding round, backed by New Enterprise Associates (NEA), Geodesic Capital and individuals including former CIA director David Petraeus. Following the announcement, a spokesperson for the company stated this will help "future proof the world". The company uses AI and machine learning to predict a variety of natural disaster impacts. For example, its Seismic Concern team examines earthquake preparedness and response, helping with the efficient dispatch of emergency workers. For now, the company looks at the United States with a focus on LA and San Francisco.
output: AI firm One Concern predicts natural disasters, secures $20m

Instances.input: Despite making accommodations to make ads more viewable, publishers are finding that the financial results may not be worth the appeal for advertisers. With advertisers demanding guaranteed viewings in exchange for large purchases, publishers expected higher value campaigns for better viewability. Instead, publishers are being restricted to performance-based ads, rather than seeing big brand interest. The price difference between highly viewable and not as viewable ads is minimal, despite an emphasis on the former for business.
output: Publishers disappointed with financial return on viewable ads

Instances.input: Nasa has revealed the two finalists for its New Frontiers competition. Comet Astrobiology Exploration Sample Return aims to explore a comet previously studied by the Rosetta mission and return a sample to Earth by 2038. Dragonfly is a project to use a drone to explore the varied terrains of Saturn's biggest moon, Titan. Both teams will be funded to the tune of $4m to develop their schemes, while Nasa will reveal the outright winner in 2019, with the mission launch planned for 2025.
output: NASA to choose between final two for 2025 New Frontier mission

Instances.input: Global B2B digital media and marketing agency DWA will be rebranded as DWA, a Merkle company after being acquired by Dentsu Aegis Network (DAN). The acquisition of DWA, whose headquarters are in San Francisco, followed similar moves into B2B by DAN, which bought B2B agencies Gyro and Band in 2015 and a majority stake in performance marketing agency Merkle last year. The president and CEO of Merkle, David Williams, said Merkle is looking to build on the rise of people-based marketing but in the B2B sector. He said: "This acquisition will strengthen our ability to deliver those capabilities at scale."
output: Dentsu Aegis Network buys global digital media agency DWA

Instances.input: Facebook is using the facial recognition technology that enables users to tag people in photos to prevent their images being used by someone else. The optional feature is a bid to curb impersonation on the social media site, and when activated, will see Facebook send notifications to users whose images have appeared on someone else's profile. However, the features only works for images that are shared publicly or among a group a user is a part of.
output: Facebook introduces facial recognition to stop online impersonation

Instances.input: Boeing has released details about a refuelling drone prototype and has plans to gain a contract from the US Navy. The unmanned aircraft system could be used in the MQ-25 Stingray programme and can refuel navy fighter jets while in flight. The remotely operated drones can be launched in the same way as the jets and can deliver up to 15,000 pounds of fuel even while 500 nautical miles from the aircraft carrier. Use of the drones would extend the range of the navy's fighter jets. The navy has opened its proposal period for rival businesses until 3 January.
output: Boeing unveils refuelling drone for aircraft carrier fighter jets

Instances.input: FinTech Australia has said that the regulatory pathway for "challenger banks" could be made easier with improvements, in response to proposed legislation from The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA). Under the legislation, ADIs would apply for a restricted license that allows them to take deposits up to $2m over a period of two years, maintaining a minimum of $3m plus wind-down costs in their reserve capital. APRA has said the pathway will make the way easier for businesses, but FinTech Australia believes the deposit limit should be $5m over a three year period.
output: Pathway for challenger banks could be improved: FinTech Australia

Instances.input: Sony's chip division, buoyed by surging sales of its image sensors, is looking to incorporate the technology in self-driving cars and robotic applications. The division claims almost half the image sensor market and was the main driver behind parent Sony's estimated JPY630bn ($5.6bn) operating profit in the year to March -- more than double the previous year's figure. Divisional chief Terushi Shimizu said the unit had flourished because it had been able to operate independently of the parent company. However, the unit faces stiff competition from rivals Samsung and OmniVision Technologies.
output: Sony chip unit eyes robotics, self-driving cars for image sensors

Instances.input: Astronauts on board the International Space Station will be growing barley seeds in the first step towards brewing beer in space. The project is a collaboration between beer manufacturer Budweiser and the Center for the Advancement of Science in Space, which aims to find out if barley will grow in a zero-gravity environment.
